title: 109_hr2297
content:
The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS; PURPOSES." summarizes the section's title, findings, and purposes. The "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act" recognizes the Arabia Mountain area's natural, cultural, historical, and recreational resources. It emphasizes the importance of partnerships between public and private entities for resource management. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve in DeKalb County, Georgia, protects various ecosystems and forests. Panola Mountain in Panola Mountain State Conservation Park is a rare granite outcrop. Miners Creek Preserve shows early human activity. Lithonia, Georgia, Arabia Mountain, and Stone Mountain exhibit the history of granite mining. Klondike is eligible for National Historic District designation. Lithonia has 2 structures on the National Register of Historic Places. The National Register of Historic Places Act aims to recognize, preserve, and promote natural, cultural, historical, and recreational resources in areas like Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, and Miners Creek. It also supports Georgia and counties in developing a program to protect and interpret significant resources within the heritage area. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

Heritage area - Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area
Management entity - DeKalb County Parks and Recreation Department or successor
Management plan - plan for the heritage area
Secretary - Secretary of the Interior
State - State of Georgia

SEC. 3. ARABIA MOUNTAIN NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA. Establishment of the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia, consisting of land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. A map is available for public inspection, and the Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance will be the management entity. Authorities and duties of the management entity are outlined. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia has the authority to make grants, hire staff, and enter into contracts. They are responsible for developing and submitting a management plan that considers the interests of various groups within the heritage area. Giving priority to certain tasks is also part of their duties. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia has the authority to prioritize actions from the management plan, assist in resource preservation, promote land use policies, conduct quarterly public meetings, and submit annual reports to the Secretary. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area in Georgia must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing accomplishments, expenses, and income. They are also required to make all records available for audit and ensure receiving organizations do the same. Federal funds under this Act cannot be used to acquire real estate. Federal funds under this Act can be used to acquire real property or an interest in real property. The management entity can also use other Federal funds for authorized purposes. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must develop a plan for the heritage area that integrates various resources and involves stakeholders. The plan should be based on the preferred concept from the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Feasibility Study. It must consider state and local plans, involve residents, public agencies, and private organizations, and include an inventory of resources in the area. The management plan for the heritage area should include a list of significant properties to be preserved, an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and interpretation of resources, an interpretation plan, and a program for implementation involving various entities. The management plan for the heritage area should include a list of significant properties to be preserved, an assessment of cultural landscapes, provisions for protection and interpretation of resources, an interpretation plan, and a program for implementation involving various entities. The plan should also involve government, private organizations, and public-private partnerships to protect resources, identify funding sources, and describe the management entity for approval by the Secretary within 3 years of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the management plan for the heritage area within 90 days of receiving it. If disapproved, the Secretary will provide reasons and recommendations for revisions to the management entity. After the Secretary approves a management plan for the heritage area, the management entity can submit revisions to the plan for approval within 90 days. The entity must periodically review the plan and suggest any necessary revisions to the Secretary for approval. The management entity can submit revisions to the approved plan for the heritage area, but no funds can be used for implementation until the Secretary approves the revision. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE. The Secretary may provide assistance to the heritage area for developing and implementing the management plan, prioritizing conservation and educational opportunities. The Act does not impose stricter regulations on occupational, safety, conservation, or environmental aspects in the heritage area than those applicable before its establishment. It also does not authorize federal agencies to introduce more stringent regulations solely due to the heritage area's creation. The Act does not change existing regulations on land use or grant zoning powers to the management entity. SEC. 8. REQUIREMENTS FOR INCLUSION OF PRIVATE PROPERTY. Private property in the Heritage Area must have owner notification and consent for preservation, conservation, or promotion by the management entity. Landowners can request removal of their property from the boundary. SEC. 9. PRIVATE PROPERTY PROTECTION. (a) Access to Private Property.--Private property owners are not required to allow public access or modify any laws regarding public access. 
(b) Liability.--Designation of the Heritage Area does not create liability for property owners for injuries on their property. 
(c) Recognition of Authority to Control Land Use.--Government authority to regulate land use is not affected. 
(d) Participation of Private Property Owners in Heritage Area.--Owners are not required to participate in the Heritage Area. The establishment of the Heritage Area and its boundaries allows for the expenditure of Federal funds within the designated area. However, it does not grant any new regulatory authority over land use to the Secretary, the National Park Service, or the management entity. Private property owners within the Heritage Area are not required to participate in or be associated with it. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $10,000,000 authorized for Act, $1,000,000 max per year. Federal share not exceed 50 percent. SEC. 11. TERMINATION OF AUTHORITY. Secretary's grant authority ends on September 30, 2016.
